bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 169, Number 50 (Friday, March 17, 2023)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. SMUCKER:H.R. 1656.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Artile I, Section 8, Clause I of the U.S. ConstitutionThe single subject of this legislation is:To establish a federal tax credit for chartible donationsby individual and corporate taxpayers to qualifying non-profit organizations providing workforce development,apprenticeship programs, career and technical education, andother workforce training.[Page H1296]

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means.

summary.text:
USA Workforce Tax Credit Act

This bill allows individual taxpayers and business entities a new tax credit for charitable contributions to a workforce development or apprenticeship training organization.

bill.title: USA Workforce Tax Credit Act

item.title: To amend the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to allow a credit against tax for charitable donations to nonprofit organizations providing workforce training.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Ways and Means.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
